elements.content: A series of new d−f heterometallic coordination frameworks, namely, [LnM(Hbic)2(ox)H2O]·2H2O [Ln = Nd, M = Cu (1); Ln = Eu, M = Ag (2); Ln = Tb, M = Ag (3); H2bic = 1H-benzimidazole-5-carboxylic acid; ox = oxalate] for type I, [LnCu(Hbic)3(ox)0.5]·H2O [Ln = Sm (4), Ln = Dy (5)] for type II, and [LnAg(Hbic)(ox)1.5] [Ln = Eu (6)] for type III, were successfully synthesized by using different metal salts and rationally controlling reaction temperature. Complexes 1−3 represent 1D polymeric chain architectures that are constructed from the connections between lanthanide-oxalate chains and M(Hbic)2 subunits. Complexes 4 and 5 are 2D layered structures which are assembled by lanthanide-oxalate and Cu(Hbic)3 units. Complex 6 exhibits another 2D layered coordination framework that is built up by tetranuclear Eu2Ag2 clusters and mixed ox and Hbic linkers. The polymeric coordination frameworks of complexes 1−6 are sustained by both hydrogen bonding and π−π stacking interactions, and they are self-assembled to form the 3D supramolecular frameworks.

elements.content: The rational design and construction of heterometallic complexes containing both lanthanide and transition metals have attracted tremendous investigation, not only because of their fascinating topology and intriguing architectures but also due to their potential applications in magnetism, luminescence, adsorption, sensors, and bimetallic catalysis. Up to date, numerous heterometallic coordination polymers have been obtained by allowing the assembly of mixed metal ions and organic ligands containing mixed-donor atoms, such as pyridinecarboxylate, amino acids, the CN group, and so on. However, the construction of designed and predictable heterometallic coordination frameworks with potential properties is still a formidable task due to the variable and high coordination numbers of the lanthanide ions, due to their low stereochemical preference, and also because of the competition between lanthanide and transition metal ions. Nevertheless, fortunately, according to the hard−soft acid base theory, the characteristics of lanthanide and transition metal ions have different affinities for N and O donors, which may provide a new avenue for the rational synthesis of novel heterometallic coordination frameworks with useful physical−chemical properties and diverse structures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational design and construction of heterometallic complexes containing both lanthanide and transition metals have attracted tremendous investigation, not only because of their fascinating topology and intriguing architectures but also due to their potential applications in magnetism, luminescence, adsorption, sensors, and bimetallic catalysis. Up to date, numerous heterometallic coordination polymers have been obtained by allowing the assembly of mixed metal ions and organic ligands containing mixed-donor atoms, such as pyridinecarboxylate, amino acids, the CN group, and so on. However, the construction of designed and predictable heterometallic coordination frameworks with potential properties is still a formidable task due to the variable and high coordination numbers of the lanthanide ions, due to their low stereochemical preference, and also because of the competition between lanthanide and transition metal ions. Nevertheless, fortunately, according to the hard-soft acid base theory, the characteristics of lanthanide and transition metal ions have different affinities for N and O donors, which may provide a new avenue for the rational synthesis of novel heterometallic coordination frameworks with useful physical-chemical properties and diverse structures.

elements.content: On the basis of our recently studies on the design and construction of unusual hetermetallic coordination frameworks using nicotinic and isonicotinic acids, we think 1H-benzimidazole-5-carboxylic acid (H2bic) is also such a potential bifunctional ligand with a carboxylate and two N-donor functional groups and can be used to construct heterometallic frameworks. Some work has been done by using H2bic as a multifunctional ligand; however, no heterometallic coordination polymers were reported. In this paper, we chose H2bic and oxalate salt as potential bridging ligands to construct heterometallic coordination polymers on the basis of the following considerations: (1) For the rigid H2bic ligand showing both oxygen and nitrogen donors, its carboxylate group prefers to bond to lanthanide (Ln) ions, while the nitrogen atom has a strong tendency to bond to transition metal (TM) ions; therefore, the soft metal copper(I)/silver(I) ion can easily coordinate to the nitrogen atom. (2) As a multidentate ligand with multiproton acceptor−donor sites, the Hbic anion includes two nitrogen atoms of an aromatic group and one carboxylate group, which might provide both hydrogen bonding donor and acceptor and π−π stacking contact in the process of self-assembly. (3) The photoluminescent property of heterometallic complexes might be influenced by the large π-conjugated system in the benzimidazole ring. (4) The oxalate ligand has versatile coordination modes, which as an auxiliary ligand, can meet the high coordination number to lanthanide metal ions.

Some work has been done by using H2bic as a multifunctional ligand; however, no heterometallic coordination polymers were reported. In this paper, we chose H2bic and oxalate salt as potential bridging ligands to construct heterometallic coordination polymers on the basis of the following considerations: (1) For the rigid H2bic ligand showing both oxygen and nitrogen donors, its carboxylate group prefers to bond to lanthanide (Ln) ions, while the nitrogen atom has a strong tendency to bond to transition metal (TM) ions; therefore, the soft metal copper(I)/silver(I) ion can easily coordinate to the nitrogen atom. (2) As a multidentate ligand with multiproton acceptor-donor sites, the Hbic anion includes two nitrogen atoms of an aromatic group and one carboxylate group, which might provide both hydrogen bonding donor and acceptor and π-π stacking contact in the process of self-assembly. (3) The photoluminescent property of heterometallic complexes might be influenced by the large π-conjugated system in the benzimidazole ring. (4) The oxalate ligand has versatile coordination modes, which as an auxiliary ligand, can meet the high coordination number to lanthanide metal ions.

elements.content: The construction of the heterometallic framworks is also influenced by many subtle factors such as temperature, pH value, solvent, template, molar ratio of raw materials, and geometries of metal ions. In the present work, we selected different Cu(I)/Ag(I) ions and lanthanide oxides to construct heterometallic complexes under different reaction temperatures. The configurations of 1−6 exhibit an increasing dimensionality spanning from one-dimensional (1−3) to two-dimensional (4−6). Besides the utilization of the metal-directed approach for building diverse coordination geometries, we also consider the effect of supramolecular interactions for extending architecture dimensionality. The polymeric coordination frameworks of complexes 1−6 are sustained by both hydrogen bonding and π−π stacking interactions and are self-assembled to form the 3D supramolecular frameworks.

elements.content: All the materials and reagents were obtained commercially and used without further purification. Elemental (C, H, N) analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 element analyzer. Infrared (IR) samples were prepared as KBr pellets, and spectra were obtained in the 4000−400 cm−1 range using a Nicolet Avatar 360 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer with the heating rate of 10 °C/min from 35 to 750 °C under dry air atmosphere. Powder XRD investigations were carried out on a Philips PW-1830 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. Fluorescence spectra were recorded with an Edinburgh FLS920 spectrophotometer analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instruments

All the materials and reagents were obtained commercially and used without further purification. Elemental (C, H, N) analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 element analyzer. Infrared (IR) samples were prepared as KBr pellets, and spectra were obtained in the 4000-400 cm-1 range using a Nicolet Avatar 360 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer with the heating rate of 10 °C/min from 35 to 750 °C under dry air atmosphere. Powder XRD investigations were carried out on a Philips PW-1830 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. Fluorescence spectra were recorded with an Edinburgh FLS920 spectrophotometer analyzer.

elements.content: Single-crystal X−ray diffraction data collections of 1−6 were performed on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer operating at 50 kV and 30 mA using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data collection and reduction were performed using the APEX II software. Multiscan absorption corrections were applied for all the data sets using the APEX II program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were placed in geometrically idealized positions and refined using a riding model. Hydrogen atoms on water molecules were located from difference Fourier maps and were also refined using a riding model. Crystallographic data for the complexes 1−6 are listed in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles for complexes 2, 4, and 6 are given in Table . In addition, selected bond lengths and angles for complexes 1, 3, and 5 are given in Table S1. CCDC numbers: 722343−722348 for complexes 1−6.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure Determination

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data collections of 1-6 were performed on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer operating at 50 kV and 30 mA using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data collection and reduction were performed using the APEX II software. Multiscan absorption corrections were applied for all the data sets using the APEX II program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were placed in geometrically idealized positions and refined using a riding model. Hydrogen atoms on water molecules were located from difference Fourier maps and were also refined using a riding model. Crystallographic data for the complexes 1-6 are listed in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles for complexes 2, 4, and 6 are given in Table . In addition, selected bond lengths and angles for complexes 1, 3, and 5 are given in Table S1. CCDC numbers: 722343-722348 for complexes 1-6.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies revealed that the three new complexes 1−3 are isomorphous, so only the structure of 2 is described in detail here. Complex 2 represents the 1D polymeric chain architecture constructed from the connections between europium-oxalate chains and Ag(Hbic)2 subunits, crystallizing in the triclinic space group P1̅. As shown in Figure , there are one Eu(III) ion, one Ag(I) ion, two Hbic anions, two halves of an oxlate anion, one coordinated and two noncoordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit, in which each Eu center is coordinated by nine oxygen donors: four oxygen atoms from two Hbic ligands, four oxygen atoms from two halves of an oxlate atom, and one oxygen atom from one water molecule. The coordination geometry around the Eu(III) center can be described as a tricapped trigonal prism geometry with the O−EuO bond angles ranging from 51.5(1) to 155.6(2)° and the Eu−O bond lengths varying from 2.388(4) to 2.541(4) Å, all of which are within the range of those observed for the other nine-coordinate Eu(III) complexes with oxygen donor ligands. As far as the Ag(I) ion in the coordination framework is concerned, it is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two different Hbic ligands with the Ag−N bond distances of 2.123(5) and 2.124(6) Å and their bond angle of 170.2(2)° (Table ). Two Hbic ligands in 2 only adopt one coordinated mode, with the nitrogen atom coordinating to one Ag(I) center and the carboxylate chelating to one Eu(III) center (Scheme a), while the ox ligands in 2 coordinate to two Eu(III) centers via a chelating coordination (Scheme d). On the basis of these connection modes of organic ligands, one Ag(I) ion is linked by two Hbic spacers to generate a Ag(Hbic)2 unit. The Ag(Hbic)2 units are connected by a 1D europium-carboxylate chain in the ac plane to form an unusual 1D heterometallic framework (Figure a). The 1D heterometallic framework is self-assembled by hydrogen bonding between one N−H and two carboxylate groups to form a 2D heterometallic supramolecular framework (Figure b).

elements.content: A surprise beyond the original crystal design, the crystallization water molecules are associated by O−H···O hydrogen bonding into cyclic centrosymmetric tetramers (Figure c). The cyclic water tetramer is formed by O1w and O2w and their centrosymmetrically related atoms. The tetramer adopts the uudd configuration. Though the uudd configuration is energetically less stable than the energy minimum udud configuration, it has been observed in other coordination frameworks. The O−H···O distances in the water tetramer range from 2.743(7) to 2.874(9) Å, while the O−H···O angles vary from 157(7) to 177(10)° (Table ). The average hydrogen bond distance within the water tetramer is 2.840 Å, which is within the range of those observed for other (H2O)4 clusters. To the best of our knowledge, complexes 1−3 represent the first d−f heterometallic coordination framework containing cyclic tetrameric water clusters. Finally, the 1D heterometallic framework is self-assembled by O−H···O and N−H···O hydrogen bonding to form a 3D heterometallic supramolecular framework.

4 and 5 are isostrutural; thus, only the structure of 4 is discussed in detail. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that polymer 4 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ and represents 2D layered structures which are assembled by samarium-oxalate and Cu(Hbic)3 units. The asymmetric unit of 4 contains one unique Sm(III) ion, one Cu(I) ion, three crystallographically unique Hbic ligands, half of an ox ligand, and one lattice molecule. The Sm(III) ion is eight coordinated and has a bicapped trigonal prism coordination geometry: six oxygen atoms from three Hbic ligands and two oxygen atoms from half of an ox ligand (Figure ). The Sm−O bond lengths range from 2.325(2) to 2.544(2) Å, and the O−SmO bond angles vary from 51.8(7) to 157.3(7)° (Table ), all of which are within the range of those observed for other eight-coordinate Sm(III) complexes with oxygen donor ligands. The Cu(I) ion is coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from three Hbic ligands with the distances of 1.947(3) to 2.000(3) Å, and their bond angles fall into the range 116.5(1)126.0(1)° (Table ). The coordination geometry around the Cu(I) center can be described as a trigonal plane geometry. In structure 4, three Hbic ligands act as two types of coordinated modes: one coordinated mode with the nitrogen atom coordinating to one Cu(I) center and the carboxylate connecting to two Sm(III) centers through a bismonodentate fashion (Scheme b), and the other coordinated mode with the nitrogen atom coordinating to one Cu(I) center and the carboxylate chelating to one Sm center (Scheme a). The ox ligands coordinate to two Sm(III) centers via a chelating coordination (Scheme c). According to the connectivity of the organic ligands, three Hbic ligands link one Cu(I) center to form a Cu(Hbic)3 unit. The Cu(Hbic)3 units are connected by the samarium-oxalate to form a 2D heterometallic layer (Figure a), which further assembled by N−H···O hydrogen bonding to form a 3D supramolecular framework (Figure b). Furthermore, the shortest distance between benzene or imidazole rings is 3.463(18) Å (Table S2), which indicates that there are weak face-to-face π−π stacking interactions in the layer. It contributes to the additional stability of the 2D heterometallic layer.

elements.content: Structure determination shows that complex 6 crystallized in the triclinic space group P1̅ and has a 2D layer structure that is built up by rare tetranuclear Eu2Ag2 clusters and mixed ox and Hbic linkers. Furthermore, the heterometallic 2D layer is assembled by hydrogen bonding to form a 3D supramolecular framework. As shown in Figure , there exist one Eu(III) ion, one Ag(I) ion, one Hbic anion, and one and a half of oxalate anions in the asymmetric unit. Each Eu(III) ion is coordinated by nine oxygen atoms from two Hbic ligands and three oxalate ligands to furnish a distorted tricapped trigonal prism geometry. The Eu−O distances are 2.406(3)2.578(3) Å, compared to those of other europium-carboxylate complexes. The O−EuO bond angles fall in the range 51.8(1)153.5(1)°. As far as Ag(I) ion in the coordination framework is concerned, it exhibits a trigonal configutation, being coordinated by one nitrogen atom from one Hbic ligand (Ag−N, 2.171(4) Å) and two oxygen atoms from two distinct ox ligands (Ag−O, 2.438(3) and 2.504(3) Å) (Table ). The Hbic ligand adopts only one coordinated mode with the nitrogen atom linked to one Ag(I) ion and the carboxylate linked to two Eu(III) ions via a chelating and bridging coordinated fashion (Scheme c). The ox ligands exhibit two kinds of coordinated modes; that is, one coordinates to two Eu(III) centers and one Ag(I) center, while the other coordinates to two Eu(III) centers and two Ag(I) centers through a chelating and bridging coordination (Scheme e and f). On the basis of these connection modes, a Eu2Ag2 cluster is formed (Figure a). As many as four Hbic ligands and four ox ligands coordinate to the Eu2Ag2 core via the benzimidazolyl nitrogen atoms and carboxylate oxygen atoms. To our knowledge, the Ln2M2 clusters are rare; only several examples have been reported previously. It is interesting that the tetranuclear ones are linked by Hbic and ox to form a 2D heterometallic Eu−Ag layer in the ac plane (Figure b). It should note that the π−π stacking interactions play a critical role in the construct of the 2D heterometallic layer with the shortest distance of 3.776(3) Å (Table S2). Therefore, the 3D supramolecular framework can be regarded as the assembly of a 2D heterometallic Eu−Ag layer via hydrogen bonding between one N−H and two carboxylate groups (Figure c).

The Eu-O distances are 2.406(3)2.578(3) Å, compared to those of other europium-carboxylate complexes. The O-EuO bond angles fall in the range 51.8(1)153.5(1)°. As far as Ag(I) ion in the coordination framework is concerned, it exhibits a trigonal configutation, being coordinated by one nitrogen atom from one Hbic ligand (Ag-N, 2.171(4) Å) and two oxygen atoms from two distinct ox ligands (Ag-O, 2.438(3) and 2.504(3) Å) (Table ). The Hbic ligand adopts only one coordinated mode with the nitrogen atom linked to one Ag(I) ion and the carboxylate linked to two Eu(III) ions via a chelating and bridging coordinated fashion (Scheme c). The ox ligands exhibit two kinds of coordinated modes; that is, one coordinates to two Eu(III) centers and one Ag(I) center, while the other coordinates to two Eu(III) centers and two Ag(I) centers through a chelating and bridging coordination (Scheme e and f). On the basis of these connection modes, a Eu2Ag2 cluster is formed (Figure a). As many as four Hbic ligands and four ox ligands coordinate to the Eu2Ag2 core via the benzimidazolyl nitrogen atoms and carboxylate oxygen atoms. To our knowledge, the Ln2M2 clusters are rare; only several examples have been reported previously. It is interesting that the tetranuclear ones are linked by Hbic and ox to form a 2D heterometallic Eu-Ag layer in the ac plane (Figure b). It should note that the π-π stacking interactions play a critical role in the construct of the 2D heterometallic layer with the shortest distance of 3.776(3) Å (Table S2). Therefore, the 3D supramolecular framework can be regarded as the assembly of a 2D heterometallic Eu-Ag layer via hydrogen bonding between one N-H and two carboxylate groups (Figure c).

elements.content: In these complexes construction, the reaction temperature and precursor metal ions have great influence on growing the single crystals. The type I complex, which features 1D polymeric chain architectures that are constructed from the connections between lanthanide-oxalate chains and M(Hbic)2 subunits, is formed at 150 °C. While at 180 °C, 2D heterometallic frameworks (type II and type III) are constructed. At the same temperature (180 °C), one discrete 3d−4f coordination framework has been afforded by using Cu(I) ions; however, by using Ag(I) ions, one rare 4d−4f cluster complex has been synthesized. Using lanthanide oxides as lanthanide sources has been proven to play a crucial role in the construction of LnM heterometallic coordination frameworks. Lanthanide ions could be slowly released to lower the polymerization rate under hydrothermal conditions, leading to high-quality single crystals. Control experiments showed that no crystals were obtained using other lanthanide(III) salts to replace lanthanide oxides under the same reaction conditions. Though the relation between the pH value and the coordination geometry has not been studied in this paper, the pH value in the system also plays a key role in the construction of Ln−M heterometallic coordination polymers, which seem to grow favorably at lower reaction pH. In addition, the π−π stacking interactions contribute to the additional stability of the 2D heterometallic complexes (4−6) and hydrogen bonding plays an important role in constructing the 3D supramolecular frameworks (1−6).

elements.content: To study the thermal stability of the three types of complexes, the thermogravimetric analyses of 1, 5, and 6 were done from 35 to 750 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in dry air atmosphere (Figure S1 of the ). For complex 1, weight loss began at 55 °C and two uncoordinated waters were lost at 136 °C (calcd/found: 5.4/6.0%), the coordinated water was lost between 170 and 222 °C (calcd/found: 2.6/2.8%). At 340 °C, the ligands started to decompose, and the residue had a composition of 1/2Nd2O3 CuO (calcd/found: 36.9/37.4%). For complex 5, the first loss of 1.7% in the range of 70−205 °C corresponded to the loss of one lattice water molecule (calcd 2.4%), the second weight loss above 310 °C corresponded to the decomposition of the coordination framework, and product may be 1/2Dy2O3 CuO (calcd/found: 34.5/36.1%). The complex 6 undergoes one step of weight loss at about 370 °C, attributing to the collapse of the whole framework and assuming the residue is 1/2Dy2O3·1/2Ag2O (calcd/found: 52.8/51.5%). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was used to confirm the purity of all complexes. As shown in Figure and Figure S2, all the peaks presented in the measured patterns closely match in the simulated patterns generated from single-crystal diffraction data.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analyses and Powder X-ray Diffraction Measurements

To study the thermal stability of the three types of complexes, the thermogravimetric analyses of 1, 5, and 6 were done from 35 to 750 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in dry air atmosphere (Figure S1 of the ). For complex 1, weight loss began at 55 °C and two uncoordinated waters were lost at 136 °C (calcd/found: 5.4/6.0%), the coordinated water was lost between 170 and 222 °C (calcd/found: 2.6/2.8%). At 340 °C, the ligands started to decompose, and the residue had a composition of 1/2Nd2O3 CuO (calcd/found: 36.9/37.4%). For complex 5, the first loss of 1.7% in the range of 70-205 °C corresponded to the loss of one lattice water molecule (calcd 2.4%), the second weight loss above 310 °C corresponded to the decomposition of the coordination framework, and product may be 1/2Dy2O3 CuO (calcd/found: 34.5/36.1%). The complex 6 undergoes one step of weight loss at about 370 °C, attributing to the collapse of the whole framework and assuming the residue is 1/2Dy2O3⋅1/2Ag2O (calcd/found: 52.8/51.5%). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was used to confirm the purity of all complexes. As shown in Figure  and Figure S2, all the peaks presented in the measured patterns closely match in the simulated patterns generated from single-crystal diffraction data.

elements.content: The IR spectra of complexes 1−3 show strong and broad absorption bands in the region of 3267−3367 cm−1, indicating the presence of water molecules. The features at 1616−1622 cm−1 and 1408−1419 cm−1 are associated with the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate groups. The IR spectra of complexes 4−5 present a broad peak in the range of 3099−3155 cm−1, also testifying the existence of a guest water molecule. The strong vibrations appearing in the regions 1651−1654 cm−1 and 1413−1417 cm−1 correspond to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate groups. The asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations at 1541, 1465, and 1396 cm−1, respectively, show that the carboxylate groups employ the chelating and bridging coordinated fashion in complex 6.
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic Studies

The IR spectra of complexes 1-3 show strong and broad absorption bands in the region of 3267-3367 cm-1, indicating the presence of water molecules. The features at 1616-1622 cm-1 and 1408-1419 cm-1 are associated with the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate groups. The IR spectra of complexes 4-5 present a broad peak in the range of 3099-3155 cm-1, also testifying the existence of a guest water molecule. The strong vibrations appearing in the regions 1651-1654 cm-1 and 1413-1417 cm-1 correspond to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate groups. The asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations at 1541, 1465, and 1396 cm-1, respectively, show that the carboxylate groups employ the chelating and bridging coordinated fashion in complex 6.

elements.content: The luminescent spectra of complexes of 2, 3, 6, and the H2bic ligand were investigated in the solid state at room temperature (Figure and Figure S3). The emission of H2bic ligand was observed at about 381 nm with a relatively intense broad band when excited at 216 nm. Under excitation of 396 nm, complex 2 yields intense red luminescence and exhibits characteristic peaks at 592, 616, 649, and 692 nm originating from the transition of 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 1 → 4) of the Eu(III) ion. The 5D0 → 7F2 transition is stronger than the 5D0 → 7F1 transition, which indicates that the Eu(III) ions have a low symmetric coordination environment. This is in agreement with the result of the single-crystal X-ray analysis. Complex 3 emits green light when excited at 320 nm, and it gives a typical Tb(III) emission spectrum. The narrow and strong peaks at 489, 545, 583, and 621 nm were ascribed to the characteristic emissions of Tb(III) corresponding to electronic transitions from the excited state 5D4 to the multiplets 7FJ (J = 6 → 3), respectively. When excitated at 396 nm, complex 6 presents the characteristic peaks at 579, 592, 615, 650, and 696 nm, which are assigned to the transition of 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0 → 4) of the Eu(III) ion. The appearance of the symmetry-forbidden emission 5D0 → 7F0 at 579 nm indicates that Eu(III) ion possesses the noncentrosymmetric coordination environment. This is also consistent with the result of the single-crystal X-ray analysis. In addition, the energy transfer from lgand-to-silver is inefficient, which is testified by no other emission peaks existing in the emission spectrum except the characteristic emission peaks of Eu(III) or Tb(III) ions.

elements.content: A series of d−f heterometallic coordination polymers have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions which exhibit a systematic variation of architectures from a 1D chain to 3D supramolecular frameworks by the employment of H2bic and ox ligands. The structural differences among 1−6 highlight the effects of temperature and metal ions on their framework construction. Moreover, the function of π−π stacking interactions and hydrogen bonding in the supramolecular framework has been studied. The thermal stability and optical properties have also been investigated. The successful preparation of the six different complexes provides a valuable approach for the construction of other novel lanthanide−transition metal coordination polymers with interesting structural, topologies, and functional properties. Further systematic studies for the design and synthesis such crystalline materials with H2bic are underway in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A series of d-f heterometallic coordination polymers have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions which exhibit a systematic variation of architectures from a 1D chain to 3D supramolecular frameworks by the employment of H2bic and ox ligands. The structural differences among 1-6 highlight the effects of temperature and metal ions on their framework construction. Moreover, the function of π-π stacking interactions and hydrogen bonding in the supramolecular framework has been studied. The thermal stability and optical properties have also been investigated. The successful preparation of the six different complexes provides a valuable approach for the construction of other novel lanthanide-transition metal coordination polymers with interesting structural, topologies, and functional properties. Further systematic studies for the design and synthesis such crystalline materials with H2bic are underway in our laboratory.

cln_elements.content:
To study the thermal stability of the three types of complexes, the thermogravimetric analyses of 1, 5, and 6 were done from 35 to 750 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in dry air atmosphere (Figure S1 of the ). For complex 1, weight loss began at 55 °C and two uncoordinated waters were lost at 136 °C (calcd/found: 5.4/6.0%), the coordinated water was lost between 170 and 222 °C (calcd/found: 2.6/2.8%). At 340 °C, the ligands started to decompose, and the residue had a composition of 1/2Nd2O3 CuO (calcd/found: 36.9/37.4%). For complex 5, the first loss of 1.7% in the range of 70−205 °C corresponded to the loss of one lattice water molecule (calcd 2.4%), the second weight loss above 310 °C corresponded to the decomposition of the coordination framework, and product may be 1/2Dy2O3 CuO (calcd/found: 34.5/36.1%). The complex 6 undergoes one step of weight loss at about 370 °C, attributing to the collapse of the whole framework and assuming the residue is 1/2Dy2O3·1/2Ag2O (calcd/found: 52.8/51.5%). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was used to confirm the purity of all complexes. As shown in Figure and Figure S2, all the peaks presented in the measured patterns closely match in the simulated patterns generated from single-crystal diffraction data.

The luminescent spectra of complexes of 2, 3, 6, and the H2bic ligand were investigated in the solid state at room temperature (Figure and Figure S3). The emission of H2bic ligand was observed at about 381 nm with a relatively intense broad band when excited at 216 nm. Under excitation of 396 nm, complex 2 yields intense red luminescence and exhibits characteristic peaks at 592, 616, 649, and 692 nm originating from the transition of 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 1 → 4) of the Eu(III) ion. The 5D0 → 7F2 transition is stronger than the 5D0 → 7F1 transition, which indicates that the Eu(III) ions have a low symmetric coordination environment. This is in agreement with the result of the single-crystal X-ray analysis. Complex 3 emits green light when excited at 320 nm, and it gives a typical Tb(III) emission spectrum. The narrow and strong peaks at 489, 545, 583, and 621 nm were ascribed to the characteristic emissions of Tb(III) corresponding to electronic transitions from the excited state 5D4 to the multiplets 7FJ (J = 6 → 3), respectively. When excitated at 396 nm, complex 6 presents the characteristic peaks at 579, 592, 615, 650, and 696 nm, which are assigned to the transition of 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0 → 4) of the Eu(III) ion. The appearance of the symmetry-forbidden emission 5D0 → 7F0 at 579 nm indicates that Eu(III) ion possesses the noncentrosymmetric coordination environment. This is also consistent with the result of the single-crystal X-ray analysis. In addition, the energy transfer from lgand-to-silver is inefficient, which is testified by no other emission peaks existing in the emission spectrum except the characteristic emission peaks of Eu(III) or Tb(III) ions.

Thermal Analyses and Powder X-ray Diffraction Measurements

To study the thermal stability of the three types of complexes, the thermogravimetric analyses of 1, 5, and 6 were done from 35 to 750 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in dry air atmosphere (Figure S1 of the ). For complex 1, weight loss began at 55 °C and two uncoordinated waters were lost at 136 °C (calcd/found: 5.4/6.0%), the coordinated water was lost between 170 and 222 °C (calcd/found: 2.6/2.8%). At 340 °C, the ligands started to decompose, and the residue had a composition of 1/2Nd2O3 CuO (calcd/found: 36.9/37.4%). For complex 5, the first loss of 1.7% in the range of 70-205 °C corresponded to the loss of one lattice water molecule (calcd 2.4%), the second weight loss above 310 °C corresponded to the decomposition of the coordination framework, and product may be 1/2Dy2O3 CuO (calcd/found: 34.5/36.1%). The complex 6 undergoes one step of weight loss at about 370 °C, attributing to the collapse of the whole framework and assuming the residue is 1/2Dy2O3⋅1/2Ag2O (calcd/found: 52.8/51.5%). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was used to confirm the purity of all complexes. As shown in Figure  and Figure S2, all the peaks presented in the measured patterns closely match in the simulated patterns generated from single-crystal diffraction data.

The luminescent spectra of complexes of 2, 3, 6, and the H2bic ligand were investigated in the solid state at room temperature (Figure  and Figure S3). The emission of H2bic ligand was observed at about 381 nm with a relatively intense broad band when excited at 216 nm. Under excitation of 396 nm, complex 2 yields intense red luminescence and exhibits characteristic peaks at 592, 616, 649, and 692 nm originating from the transition of 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 1 → 4) of the Eu(III) ion. The 5D0 → 7F2 transition is stronger than the 5D0 → 7F1 transition, which indicates that the Eu(III) ions have a low symmetric coordination environment. This is in agreement with the result of the single-crystal X-ray analysis. Complex 3 emits green light when excited at 320 nm, and it gives a typical Tb(III) emission spectrum. The narrow and strong peaks at 489, 545, 583, and 621 nm were ascribed to the characteristic emissions of Tb(III) corresponding to electronic transitions from the excited state 5D4 to the multiplets 7FJ (J = 6 → 3), respectively. When excitated at 396 nm, complex 6 presents the characteristic peaks at 579, 592, 615, 650, and 696 nm, which are assigned to the transition of 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0 → 4) of the Eu(III) ion. The appearance of the symmetry-forbidden emission 5D0 → 7F0 at 579 nm indicates that Eu(III) ion possesses the noncentrosymmetric coordination environment. This is also consistent with the result of the single-crystal X-ray analysis. In addition, the energy transfer from lgand-to-silver is inefficient, which is testified by no other emission peaks existing in the emission spectrum except the characteristic emission peaks of Eu(III) or Tb(III) ions.
